age: 45. gender: F. Name: ___ Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: F Service: MEDICINE Allergies: epinephrine Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: abdominal pain Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: Diagnostic paracentesis on ___ Therapeutic paracentesis on ___ History of Present Illness: ___ female with h/o EtOH abuse p/w abdominal pain. Patient is poor historian but states that she has had a distended abdomen in the past and recently underwent therapeutic paracentesis ___ days ago at ___ which was only the ___ or ___ time that she has had a paracentesis. She was discharged on several new medications but she has not been taking them. She does not know why are belly swells, but she thinks its because she drinks. She reports several episodes of vomiting and diarrhea but cannot recall quantity or quality. She states that she saw her PCP today in ___, and was sent to ___ for further evaluation ___ to her distended abdomen. Initial ED VS, Pain 10 T99 P96 BP 119/85 RR16 O2 sat 98% RA. Labs were notable for normal labs except for mildly elevated AP of 145. A diagnostic para was performed and was negative for SBP. She was given zofran and morphine and admitted to medicine for further evaluation. Vitals prior to transfer: Pain 8 T98 P87 BP113/80 RR16 O2 sat 96% RA. On the floor, VS: T99.2 BP 109/72 P98 RR20 O2 sat 98%RA. Patient has no complaints except for abdominal pain. She is tearful when talking about why her alcohol consumption has increased. She has a bag a new medications including lasix, spironolactone, azithro and levofloxacin, but pt is unsure why she was prescribed this medications. She says they were all for her abdomen. On ROS, patient denies fevers, chills, CP, SOB, nausea,constipation, ___ edema. Past Medical History: - EtOH abuse - Cirrhosis - Ascites - HTN Social History: ___ Family History: noncontributory Physical Exam: Admission Physical Exam Vitals- T99.2 BP 109/72 P98 RR20 O2 sat 98%RA General- Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT- Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck- supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD Lungs- CTAB, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV- RRR, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen- firm, distended abdomen, + fluid wave, diffusely TTP, non-distended, hypoactive BS, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly appreciable GU- no foley Ext- warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis, trace edema bilaterally Neuro- CNs2-12 intact, motor function grossly normal, no asterixis Discharge Physical Exam: Vitals- BP (lying 85/58, sitting 101/56, Standing 90/59). HR 60-70 lying to standing. RR 16 General- Alert, oriented, soft spoken, making little eye contact in NAD HEENT- Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck- no elevated JVP Lungs- CTAB CV- RRR, no MRG Abdomen- firm, nondistended, slight bulge of her umbilical hernia. site of para on LLQ with bag over large amoutn of para fluid present within. mildly tender to palpation. GU- no foley Ext- warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis, trace edema bilaterally Neuro- CNs2-12 intact, motor function grossly normal, no asterixis, good attention, a+Ox3 Pertinent Results: Admission labs ___ 04:20PM BLOOD WBC-9.3 RBC-4.62 Hgb-14.5 Hct-43.0 MCV-93 MCH-31.3 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.7 Plt ___ ___ 04:20PM BLOOD Neuts-81.4* Lymphs-13.8* Monos-4.0 Eos-0.2 Baso-0.7 ___ 04:20PM BLOOD ___ PTT-34.6 ___ ___ 04:20PM BLOOD Glucose-103* UreaN-6 Creat-0.5 Na-133 K-4.4 Cl-99 HCO3-26 AnGap-12 ___ 04:20PM BLOOD ALT-16 AST-32 AlkPhos-145* TotBili-0.8 ___ 07:40AM BLOOD Albumin-2.3* Calcium-8.3* Phos-4.3# Mg-1.7 Pertinent labs ___ 07:40AM BLOOD HBsAg-NEGATIVE HBsAb-NEGATIVE HBcAb-NEGATIVE HAV Ab-POSITIVE ___ 07:40AM BLOOD AMA-NEGATIVE Smooth-NEGATIVE ___ 07:40AM BLOOD ___ ___ 07:40AM BLOOD AFP-2.2 ___ 04:20PM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG ___ 07:40AM BLOOD HCV Ab-NEGATIVE Discharge labs ___ 10:15AM BLOOD WBC-5.1 RBC-3.56* Hgb-11.0* Hct-33.7* MCV-95 MCH-30.9 MCHC-32.7 RDW-13.6 Plt ___ ___ 10:15AM BLOOD Glucose-114* UreaN-10 Creat-0.4 Na-131* K-4.3 Cl-97 HCO3-28 AnGap-10 ___ 01:14AM URINE Color-Straw Appear-Clear Sp ___ ___ 01:14AM URINE Blood-TR Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.5 Leuks-SM ___ 01:14AM URINE RBC-1 WBC-3 Bacteri-FEW Yeast-NONE Epi-1 ___ 05:50PM ASCITES WBC-55* RBC-658* Polys-4* Lymphs-23* Monos-8* Mesothe-9* Macroph-56* ___ 05:50PM ASCITES TotPro-1.3 Glucose-118 Albumin-<1.0 Microbiology ___ BLood cultures- NEGATIVE x2 ___ BLood culture NGTD ___ 5:50 pm PERITONEAL FLUID **FINAL REPORT ___ GRAM STAIN (Final ___: 1+ (<1 per 1000X FIELD): POLYMORPHONUCLEAR LEUKOCYTES. NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN. This is a concentrated smear made by cytospin method, please refer to hematology for a quantitative white blood cell count.. FLUID CULTURE (Final ___: NO GROWTH. ANAEROBIC CULTURE (Final ___: NO GROWTH. Imaging: CXR ___: IMPRESSION: Low lung volumes with bibasilar atelectasis and trace right pleural effusion. No subdiaphragmatic free air seen. RUQ ultrasound ___: IMPRESSION: 1. Nodular liver with coarsened echotexture and large volume ascites, compatible with hepatic cirrhosis. 2. The portal vein is patent with normal hepatopetal flow. 3. 1.1 cm hyperechoic lesion adjacent to the falciform ligament for which further characterization with dedicated MRI is recommended. CT abdomen ___: 1. Nodular liver with large volume simple ascites, which can be seen in the setting of cirrhosis. Although no discrete peritoneal enhancement is seen, underlying peritonitis cannot be excluded, and clinical correlation with possible fluid sampling is recommended 2. No signs of loculated fluid collection or bowel perforation. Normal appendix. 3. Cholelithiasis with no evidence of cholecystitis. 4. Small nonhemorrhagic right pleural effusion. Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F w/ PMH of presumed alcohol cirrhosis here with abdominal pain and increased girth secondary to worsening ascites who was discharged with improved pain. Acute Issues: #Abdominal pain- likely secondary to increased ascites as there was no intraperitoneal disease found on CT scan. Furthermore her pain improved with therapeutic paracentis of 6.5L. Her diagnostic paracentesis was negative for SBP. Ascites fluid leak - due to persist fluid leak a suture was placed by surgery. #This was successful in stopping the leak. Suture may be removed in approx 10 days from placement on the day of discharge. #Cirrhosis- patient reported receiving her previous care at ___. When she presented she had evidence of large amount of ascites. Normal coags and plateltes and low albumin. She had a therapeutic paracentesis -6.5L, and had leaking para site on the LLQ that required a figure 8 stitch to be placed to stop the leaking. She reported still drinking alcohol. Labs performed here were negative for other sources of cirrhosis detectable by lab serology. She had no evidence of encephalopathy, no spider angiomas. Her blood pressure ran low and she had mild hyponatremia. Due to her low blood pressure (80s/50s) it was decided to hold her diuretics on discharge and that she would followup with her PCP in ___ couple of days to repeat her blood pressure and restart diuretics at a low dose. She was counseled on adhering to a low sodium diet and fluid restriction of 2L. Suture to be removed the week of ___ will have followup in the ___ clinic with Dr. ___ on ___. #Alcohol use- patient with alcohol use. She had presumed alcohol cirrhosis secondary to it. She was placed on the CIWA scale and never scored or showed signs of withdrawal. #Low blood pressure- patient had blood pressure in the ___. She had no orthostaic symptoms and her blood pressure increased with sitting and standing. Her urine was dilute and therefore it was felt that this was not secondary to volume depletion and could be due to her underlying liver disease. Chronic/transitional Issue: #Hypertension- patient reported being on HCTZ on admission. This was held during her stay and at the time of discharge. We do not anticipate restarting as an outpatient as the pt appears to have low BPs chronically from cirrhosis. Medications on Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Spironolactone 50 mg PO DAILY 2. Levofloxacin 250 mg PO Q24H 3. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 4. Azithromycin 500 mg PO Q24H 5. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY 6. Spectravite Adult 50+ (multivit-min-FA-lycopen-lutein;
mv-min-folic acid-lutein) 0.4-300-250 mg-mcg-mcg oral daily 7. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY 8. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY Discharge Medications: 1. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY 2. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY 3. Spectravite Adult 50+ (multivit-min-FA-lycopen-lutein;
mv-min-folic acid-lutein) 0.4-300-250 mg-mcg-mcg oral daily 4. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO QID:PRN reflux Discharge Disposition: Home Discharge Diagnosis: Decompensated cirrhosis with ascites Hypotension Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Discharge Instructions: Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted to the hospital with worsening abdominal pain. You had excessive fluid in your abdomen due to too much salt and fluid intake and not taking your diuretics (water pills). You had this fluid removed by paracentesis. You had some continued output from the paracentesis site and had a stitch placed. This stitch should remain in place for 1 week and removed by a clinician at that time. It is very important that you avoid salt in your diet and do not take in too much fluid. We also recommend that you cut down on your alcohol use and seek assistance in ways to do this safely if you choose to do it. Followup Instructions: ___ Output:

||startoftext||The patient is a 45-year-old female with a history of EtOH abuse, cirrhosis, and ascites. She presented with abdominal pain and was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. Her chief complaint was abdominal pain, which was likely secondary to increased ascites. She had a diagnostic paracentesis, which was negative for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). She was given zofran and morphine and admitted to medicine for further evaluation.

The patient has a past medical history of EtOH abuse, cirrhosis, and ascites. She has allergies to epinephrine. She was prescribed several medications, including lasix, spironolactone, azithromycin, and levofloxacin, but was unsure why she was prescribed these medications.

The patient's physical exam revealed a firm, distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave and diffusely tender to palpation. She had no organomegaly appreciable. Her discharge physical exam revealed a firm, nondistended abdomen with a slight bulge of her umbilical hernia.

The patient's laboratory results showed mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase and normal liver function tests. Her urine analysis showed a trace of protein and a few white blood cells. Her ascites fluid analysis showed a high white blood cell count and a high protein level.

The patient's imaging studies showed low lung volumes with bibasilar atelectasis and a small right pleural effusion on chest X-ray. Her RUQ ultrasound showed a nodular liver with coarsened echotexture and large volume ascites, compatible with hepatic cirrhosis. Her CT abdomen showed a nodular liver with large volume simple ascites and no signs of loculated fluid collection or bowel perforation.

The patient's hospital course was marked by an acute issue of abdominal pain, which was likely secondary to increased ascites. She had a therapeutic paracentesis of 6.5L and had a persisting fluid leak, which was successfully stopped with a suture. She was discharged with improved pain and was advised to follow up with her PCP in a couple of days to repeat her blood pressure and restart diuretics. ||endoftext||

who presents with cough and shortness of breath
.  
#  Cough- Patient was recently admitted with similar symptoms at 
___ and was discharged with a course of augmentin and 
doxycycline for CAP, which she completed.  However, prior to 
admission, she developed cough associated with shortness of 
breath so she presented to ___.   In the ED, she was febrile 
with possible early pneumonia on CXR, so she received a dose of 
ceftriaxone.  Given that her WBC was normal, and cough was 
non-productive, the patient was not initially treated for HCAP.  
In addition, she has presented like this in the past and was 
treated for a COPD exacerbation.  On admission, she was started 
on azithromycin, prednisone 60mg daily and nebulizers.  Her 
symptoms improved and oxygen requirement was decreasing.  
However, she developed a fever on ___ so she was started on 
vancomycin and cefepime for HCAP, given recent hospital 
discharge.  She was weaned off oxygen and worked well with 
physical therapy.  Urine legionella was negative.  Blood and 
urine cultures were negative.  Sputum culture was contaminated 
with normal respiratory flora.  The patient completed an 8 day 
course of antibiotics- vancomycin 1gm q48hours, Cefepime 1g q24 
hours via ___ line.  She is being discharged on a prednisone 
taper starting at 30mg daily.  On discharge, cough, shortness of 
breath and oxygen requirement had resolved.  She was able to 
ambulate with no shortness of breath.  The patient was afebrile 
from ___ until discharge, had a normal WBC count and looked 
well.  
.  
#  Fever- Likely secondary to pneumonia.  She lacked other 
symptoms of influenza (myalgias, etc).  Patient's cultures were 
negative.  UA was negative for UTI.  
.
#  COPD- Patient improved with azithromycin, nebulizers and 
steroids.  She was weaned off oxygen and is being discharged on 
a prednisone taper, starting at 30mg daily for 14 additional 
days of therapy
.  
#  Atrial fibrillation- Continued home amiodarone and 
metoprolol.  Heart rate was regular and was well-controlled.  
Her INR trended up to 4.3 so she was cut down from 2mg 3x/week 
to 0.5 or 1.0mg daily (pending INR) given that she is on 
antibiotics and amiodarone.  As mentioned, her INR peaked at 4.3 
but then trended down.  We resumed her at 2mg daily on ___ 
when INR was 1.7.  Subsequent trend was 1.7 -> 1.5 -> 1.6.  She 
received 2mg of coumadin on ___.  We have 
instructed her to resume her prior regimen on discharge meaning 
she will take 2mg on ___ and 1mg on ___.  We also asked the 
patient to have an INR check on ___ and to please fax the 
results to her PCP for instruction on management of coumadin 
dosing.  
.  
#  Diastolic CHF- The patient has a known history of chronic 
diastolic heart failure.  On admission, there were no signs of 
fluid overload on exam.  Her oxygen requirement was attributed 
to pneumonia and COPD exerbation.  Given her elevated creatinine 
on admission, her lasix and lisinopril were initially held.  Her 
creatinine improved so we resumed her lisinopril at 20mg daily.  
By discharge, we resumed home dose of lisinopril.  Once 
creatinine stabilized, home dose of lasix was resumed and 
patient's creatinine remained stable.  She was discharged on 
home dose of lasix 20mg daily and has ___ with Dr. ___ 
on ___.
.
#  CAD- The patient did not present with chest pain.  Her EKGs 
were consistent with prior.  She was continued on her home 
statin and beta-blocker.  
.
#  Hypertension- As mentioned above, her lisinopril was 
initially held given ___ but was resumed at home dose by 
discharge.  She was continued on the remainder of her home 
medications- imdur 30mg daily, metoprolol 50mg BID and 
nifedipine 60mg daily.  BP's were remained stable. 
.
#  Numbness- On the last day of admission, patient revealed to 
us that she had been experiencing numbness in her fingertips 
(all of them).  Exam did not demonstrate any sensory or motor 
deficit as patient has ___ strength in all 4 extremities with 
intact sensation bilaterally.  She is not a diabetic.  Other 
possible etiologies include b12 deficiency, radiculopathy, or 
vasculitis.  Given that her symptoms are in both hands with only 
the DIP joint affected, a cervical radiculopathy is unlikely.  
She has no other systemic symptoms suggestive of vasculitis 
(skin changes, fever, chills) and her labwork is benign.  No 
indication for imaging as remainder of neurological exam is 
intact, including gait.  This also could be due to a medication 
as she received IV antibiotics.  B12 level checked and pending 
at the time of discharge, but, given description of symptoms, 
will likely not be the etiology behind this numbness.  We ask 
that the patient's PCP ___ on this issue when she sees the 
patient on ___.
.
# Prophylaxis:  DVT ppx with coumadin, bowel regimen senna, 
colace, pain management with tylenol
.  
# Code: Full (confirmed)  
.  
# Emergency Contact:  Daughter ___ ___

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 91-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of cough and fever. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. She was previously admitted to the hospital with a similar condition and was discharged with a course of antibiotics, which she completed. However, her symptoms persisted, and she presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath. On admission, she was febrile with possible early pneumonia on chest X-ray, and she received a dose of ceftriaxone. Her white blood cell count was normal, and her cough was non-productive, so she was not initially treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia. She was started on azithromycin, prednisone, and nebulizers, and her symptoms improved. ||endoftext||

CXR:  In comparison with study of ___, there is no change or 
evidence of 
acute cardiopulmonary disease. Specifically, no focal pneumonia 
or 
interstitial prominence to suggest PCP. 

U/S liver: 
1. Thickened gallbladder wall with no gallstones. Thick-walled 
bile ducts 
with no biliary dilatation. The appearance of these structures 
is consistent 
with HIV choliangiopathy. 
2. Focal fat seen within the liver.  
3. Mild splenomegaly. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w/ AIDS off HAART for 15 months presents w/ malaise, 
anemia.
.
#HIV: Pt. has had poor reactions to ARV Tx in the past (stopped 
taking because of nausea w/ ritonavir), pt. restarted on ARV w/ 
attention to this. Pt. did well w/ no N/V after taking ritonavir 
at HS. Blood cultures were drawn for bacteria, mycobacteria and 
fungi and were no growth to date on day of D/C. Continued 
dapsone ppx, but considered switching to atovaquone because of 
hemolytic anemia, Hct remained stable so we kept pt. on dapsone.

.
#Abdominal pain: Pt. has Hx of bowel wall ulcer, this seems 
probable as his tenderness is extremely localized, has not been 
progressive. Likely he does not have acute bacterial issue as he 
is non septic and this has been present for a long time. He has 
been scoped before w/ conflicting path results (negative CMV Cx 
but a few inclusions),consider CMV colitis, Consider HSV 
colitis, Consider parasitic ___. Dr. ___ 
performed the endoscopy felt that the ulcer looked like it was 
from CMV and so pt. was empirically started on IV gancyclovir 
and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir after 2 days. The 
abdominal pain seemed to improve slightly day to day. Pt. had 
elevated alk phos, GGT, Tbili so liver U/S was performed and wet 
read was consistent w/ HIV cholangiopathy.
.
#Anemia: Appears to be hemolytic as haptoglobin was decreased to 
<20 and retic count is elevated. Elevated retic count (not 
appropriately elevated given low Hbg) suggests that there is a 
lack of production. He recieved 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct 
increased to above 25 and remained stable after transfusion, on 
day of d/c was 24.9. Likely that he is no longer hemolyzing, but 
unknown whether his marrow is responding at time of d/c. There 
was significant concern that the lack of marrow response 
represented a marrow infiltrative process so a BMB was obtained. 
Results of BMB were pending at D/C.
.
#Fever: Likely OI as pt. has no other focal signs of infection. 
Could be drug fever as pt. recently started on gancyclovir and 
ARV's, the fevers did not appear until the night after the 
gancyclovir was started and continued to wax and wane and he had 
a temperature to 100.8 the night before d/c. CXR, UA, Ucx, Blood 
Cx X3 sets routine Negative so far. Pt. to f/u w/ Dr. ___ 
results of BMB and mycolytic blood cultures.
.
#Fatigue: likely ___ anemia, but may also be due to chronic OI 
and/or HIV wasting syndrome as pt. appeared quite cachectic. 
Nutrition was consulted and recommended ensure supplementation, 
but pt. did not like ensure and made this clear to nutrition, 
ensure was seen unopened on pt.s tray every morning.
.
#Diarrhea: Likely ___ OI, differential is quite wide: crypto, 
giardia, ___, CMV, C. diff. All previous wkup 
was negative in ___.  Likely etiology is an OI which will be 
treated by increasing his CD4 count. Repeat stool studies were 
negative for o/p, ___, crypto, giardia, cyclospora.
.
#Hyponatremia: Possibly secondary to diarrhea with free water 
replacement or SIADH from chronic pain. Most likelly from 
diarrhea. Urine lytes, Cr, Osm inconclusive for SIADH vs. volume 
depletion. FeNa was 1.6. Pt. remained asymptomatic and recieved 
no specific treatment.
.
#Elevated alk phos: Likely bile duct source as GGT also 
elevated. Pt. also complaining of RUQ pain and tenderness, has 
previous history of U/S which showed cholelithiasis. Liver U/S 
did not show stones in duct, wet read was consistent with HIV 
cholangiopathy.

 
Medications on Admission:
Dapsone 100mg QD
Albuterol 2 puffs PRN

Two (2) Puffs Inhalation PRN as needed for shortness of breath

Home

Primary
Hemolytic anemia.
bone marrow dysfunction
HIV

Depression

Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have been diagnosed with hemolytic anemia and inappropriate 
bone marrow response. The results of some tests as to the cause 
are still pending. The results of your bone marrow biopsy are 
also pending. Please follow up with Dr. ___ the results 
of your tests. We were not able to find the cause of your 
chronic diarrhea although cytomegalovirus is suspected and you 
are being treated with valgancyclovir 900mg twice daily.

Please take all of your medications exactley as prescribed.

Please return to the emergency department if you experience any 
worsening fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, 
confusion, bleeding, black tarry stools, fatigue or any other 
concerning symptoms.

Please make a follow up appointment with Dr. ___ ___

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 55-year-old male with a chief complaint of fatigue. He has a history of AIDS, diagnosed 15 months prior, and has been off antiretroviral therapy (ARV) for 15 months. He presents with anemia, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, which has been present for a year. He has a history of depression, situational depression, and has experienced weight loss. His physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, hard white plaques on the sides of his tongue, and multiple umbilicated papules on his face. His laboratory results show anemia, elevated liver enzymes, and hyponatremia. He was started on IV gancyclovir and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir for suspected CMV colitis. He received 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct increased to above 25. He was also started on dapsone prophylaxis. His discharge medications include dapsone 100mg QD and valgancyclovir. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 64-year-old female who presented with an inferior STEMI. She has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, fibromyalgia, spinal stenosis, chronic pain syndrome, depression, and bilateral cataracts. She has a family history of premature coronary artery disease in her father, who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. 

The patient's allergies include penicillins and ibuprofen. She was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of chest pain and was found to have an 80% stenosis at the bifurcation of the LAD and OM, which was too difficult to stent due to concern for jailing the artery. She also had a 90% lesion to the mid RCA, which was stented with a DES. 

The patient's medications at discharge include ASA, morphine, lopressor, heparin, plavix, and integrallin. Her physical examination was normal, with no signs of chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Her laboratory results showed normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with elevated troponin and creatine kinase levels. 

The patient's diagnosis is two-vessel coronary artery disease, with successful stenting of the mid-RCA with a Cypher DES. Her echocardiogram showed normal left atrial size, left ventricular wall thickness, and regional/global systolic function, with mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. ||endoftext||
